author: Shoumojit Banerjee
text:
free at last:Sanjay Dutt, along with wife Manyata and children Shahran and Iqra, at a press conference at his residence in Mumbai on Thursday; the actor’s fans celebrate his release.— PHOTOs: PTI , Vivek Bendre

The actor was granted reprieve on grounds of ‘good behaviour’

Bollywood actor Sanjay Dutt walked out from Pune’s high-security Yerwada Central Jail on Thursday morning, eight months before completing a five-year sentence for his role in the 1993 Mumbai serial blasts.

The 56-year-old Dutt has often been accused of being given preferential treatment during his prison term mired in controversy, during which he spent more than three months on furloughs and paroles.

A phalanx of security personnel shielded Mr. Dutt from the media as he emerged out of prison with a palpable sense of relief at 8.30 a.m. after fulfilling the formalities.

There was a touch of drama as the actor, who was granted a reprieve for ‘good behaviour’, saluted the prison on coming out and then trudged ahead with a large bag on his shoulders.

“There is no easy walk to freedom, my friends,” said a terse Mr. Dutt at the Pune airport, straining to escape the battery of journalists.

He was met by his wife Manyata, while director Rajkumar Hirani, who directed him in the popular Munnabhai blockbusters, was there to greet him at the Pune airport.

The actor flew to Mumbai in a chartered plane. After landing, the actor visited the Siddhivinayak temple and his mother Nargis Dutt’s grave. He returned to his home in Bandra to a grand and emotional welcome from his family.

Mr. Dutt, who has a slew of film projects lined up, was serving the remainder of his five-year sentence for illegal possession and destruction of an AK-56 rifle before the 1993 Mumbai blasts, in which over 250 people were killed.

A petition challenging his release in the Bombay High Court was posted for hearing on Monday.

‘I am not a terrorist’

“I am not a terrorist. I have been honourably acquitted by the Tada court from both the conspiracy and terror charges in the 1993 bomb blasts case. I was convicted in the Arms Act, a conviction which even the Supreme Court has upheld. I was acquitted of Section 120 (b) and all Tada charges. I request the media not to mention the 1993 bomb blasts. Because I was not involved in it,” the 56-year-old actor said during a media interaction at his Imperial Heights residence in Bandra, surrounded by his close family and friends.

“I have been waiting for 23 years to get a taste of freedom. Finally, that day has arrived, and I am a free man. That feeling is still not sinking in. I feel like I am on furlough or leave from jail. It will take me some time to convince myself that I am free,” Dutt told reporters.

Dutt said he missed and remembered his father Sunil Dutt the most as he had waged a legal and political battle to get the “terrorist” tag removed from his name. “Honourable Judge Kode said you wanted to know if you are a terrorist, and the court says you are not a terrorist. I wish my father had heard that. The Supreme Court also endorsed it, and whatever sentence I was awarded I have completed,” he said.

As prisoner number 16656 in Yerwada jail, Dutt was trained to weave chairs, and make environment-friendly paper bags during his 835-day stay. He was also part of a community radio initiative where he was one of the radio jockeys.

“The prison regime included listening to songs on radio from 11a.m. to 4 p.m. Prison inmates were told about behavioural improvement and rehabilitation so that there is a message along with entertainment. I spoke about my experiences, about the film industry. I did whatever I could do,” Dutt said adding that he handed the sum of Rs 440 he earned at the jail to his wife.

Hugging his twins Shahran and Iqra, Dutt said he was looking forward to spending time with his family and children.

“Most of all, I want to get back to my work,” he said.
title: Sanjay Dutt leaves Pune prison eight months early
